headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Independent Candidates Derail Biden and Trump; RFK Polling for Third-Party. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Wow.Dana Bash, thank you for being with us.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We can't wait to watch. Everyone should watch Dana's new episode of "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER." A whole hour, a whole story. It airs Sunday, 9So, could 2024 be the year a third-party candidate spoils the race for president? Early polls closer than you might think.

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And along those lines, you might know him from dropping the people's elbow on wrestlers in the ring, but could he also be the people's president? That was a WWF reference, Poppy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you think I'm not an expert, Mattingly?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Could an independent candidate play a spoiler role in this presidential race? New polling says potentially, yes. RFK Jr. declared last month he'd run as an independent. Rumors swirling this morning that retiring Senator Joe Manchin could be considering the same.With us now, senior data reporter, Harry Enten. Harry, good morning. Let's start with RFK Jr.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes, let's start with RFK Jr. And he is getting -- look at these loads of likely voters choosing RFK in key swing states. Twenty-four percent in Arizona, 23 percent in Georgia, 25 percent in Michigan, you see 19 percent in Nevada, 21 in Pennsylvania, 21 in Wisconsin. High teens, low-to-mid 20s across the board.And that is historic because independents who polled over 20 percent within a year of the election, we got RFK Jr., there hasn't been anybody polling this high, this late since Ross Perot in '92, John Anderson in '80, George Wallace in '68. And, of course, all those folks ended up with at least high single digits, if not all the way up to near 20 percent in the case of Ross Perot.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Harry, I think George H.W. Bush had some thoughts about Ross Perot and his impact on 1992. What impact could RFK have on the Biden/Trump matchup if that happens?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, remember those "New York Times" polls that we spoke about earlier this week, and they were such bad news for Joe Biden. But look at this, the Biden versus Trump margin without Kennedy, look at that, we see Trump up by five in Arizona, five in Pennsylvania, 11 points in Nevada. You add Kennedy, look at this, you end up with a tie in Arizona, a tie in Pennsylvania, and that lead gets cut down to six points in Nevada. So, Kennedy could, in fact, be a spoiler for Donald Trump, at least according to this poll.Of course, I will note, Phil and Poppy, he's not the only potential third-party candidate who could play a role. Joe Manchin, of course, announced that he's retiring from the Senate from West Virginia. There's thoughts of him running as a No Labels party candidate. Look at this, 10 percent of registered voters said that they may, in fact, vote for him. So, this year we could end up with a major party candidate winning the race with far less than 50 and maybe less than 40 percent of the vote.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And that's numbers from even before, you know, last night happened.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Even before he announced, exactly.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Harry, that was so good we'd like you to come hang out with us for a little bit long.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Is there a bar to being invited to the table, Phil?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Like, walk over here.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: You want me to walk - I would - (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: All right, Harry, stick around. We want to bring back in CNN's John Avlon and also CNN political analyst and vice president of the digital content at "theGrio" weekly, Natasha Alford.Guys, thanks so much for joining us. Avlon, you can't match that. Don't even try. No, I'm kidding. RFK Jr., I'm -- just to ask kind of the obvious, what's up with that?

utterances.speaker: JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: NATASHA ALFORD, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: What's happening?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And I don't mean that in like a pejorative. It's fascinating because it has been consistent and it has not been like a two-week thing.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: I'm sure the Democratic establishment would love to sort of dismiss this candidate, right? He's very inconvenient. But I think it's the name recognition. I think it's people's hunger for something else. The polls have told us again and again, even though we're a year out, that people are not excited about the Trump/Biden matchup. And so maybe he evokes, you know, sort of nostalgia for an America of the past with the Kennedy name, but he has a very interesting bag of policy proposals, raising the minimum wage, he's an environmentalist, he's interested in criminal justice reform. So, maybe for voters who were never going to vote for Biden or Trump, they want to throw their hat in the ring with this one.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: Jill Stein and Hillary Clinton, right, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, Jill Stein made that difference for Hillary Clinton and -

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Three states, yes.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: People are still, you know, salty about that today.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I just think it's -- the thing that I should note is Donald Trump, you know, he -- when he won in 2016, didn't come anywhere close to crossing the 50 percent threshold.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: What's going to be very interesting this time around is, we could end up with the winner of this presidential election, at least in the popular vote, who could get south of say Bill Clinton's, you know, 43 percent that he got in 1992. We could end up with a president who really doesn't have much of a mandate from anybody given how unpopular both Biden and Trump are.And that, let's be real, is the real reason why these third-party and independent candidates are doing so well in the polls, it's because these are the two major -- most least liked major party candidates at this point in the campaign basically ever.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I want to play something from a -- maybe another potential third-party candidate, maybe not. We don't know. "The Rock."(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DWAYNE "THE ROCK" JOHNSON: In 2022, I got a visit from the parties asking me if I was going to run, and if I could run.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: And it's a big deal. And it came out of the blue.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: And it was one after the other.I was moved by that. And the reason why I have given that response, if that's truly what the people want, then of course I will consider it. And after that response, that's when the parties came. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: The Rock-obama.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That was good.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's good. That was very good.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: That's the energy he gives.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: A point of clarity, the parties are not one autonomous being that approaches people to ask for things. So, that can mean a lot of different things.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: The party.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: The giant (ph) elephant.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I don't doubt he was approached. It could have been by -

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Operatives approached "The Rock," yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You're going to try to ask a serious question now, Mattingly, on that?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: No. I mean, look, here's - here's why I would ask a serious question. I don't think this pertains to 2024.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: By the way, I'm a huge "Rock" fan.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The reason why I'm so fascinated by it is because of that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: People love the guy. His Q (ph) score, if I understood what that was, would - I assume is positively enormous.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It rivals yours.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And, oh, by the way, we've seen a celebrity win a presidency. So --

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: And Jesse Ventura, WWF.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, and governorships.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: Governor of Minnesota.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Ronald Reagan, lest we forget.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Important difference being that Ronald Reagan was a two-term governor of California before he ran for president. Look, there's this fascinating perennial fascination with "The Rock"running. And I think it's because he's a disciplined guy, he's an engaging guy, he's expressed an interest in civic service.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: But I think, two things. One, it shows that people are desperate for non-politicians to run. And, two, it shows why historically, up until Donald Trump, that celebrities who want to run for president run for some other public office to get some chops. Jesse Ventura being another example. Arnold Schwarzenegger couldn't run for president but was a very popular and effective two-term governor for California as well.So, I just think that, you know, there's this gravitational pull this - we're trying to draw "The Rock" in. It's a symbol of people's dissatisfaction and the fact they want people who they know outside of politics. But I'd like to see people who -- if they're interested in something as civically sacred as running for president run for another office first.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I would just put - bring in an international example. Right now President Zelenskyy is leading Ukraine through a time of war.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: And he was a comedian. That was what he was best known as for. And I think when you have people who are so dissatisfied with the two- party system, they're willing to try something very, very different because they figure the politician, as usual, simply put, aren't working.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's a great point about the landscape.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: Yes, Donald Trump, I think, lowered the bar for some people. Never - never served before. So, if Donald Trump could be president, some people think "The Rock" could be president.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys, very much.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Country over party.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Stay with us.Ahead, federal law enforcement this morning on high alert after these suspicious letters were sent to election offices across the country. Some of them laced with fentanyl. The latest on that investigation ahead.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Story of the week. Update this morning on our international panda watch. The giant pandas that left the National Zoo in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, they have arrived in China. My mom asked me if they flew Delta. Their departure - it's true. Their departure marked the end of more than 50 years of Chinese pandas being housed at the zoo. It's sad to see them go. The zoo staff called it a hiatus in their wildly popular panda program. Chinese officials have yet to say whether they will ever return to the zoo.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And another serious update. Earlier this week during our show I revealed my affinity for a different species of mammal native to Asia.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I do have to say, David, if you don't mind, because I know how well sourced you are both in China and here, a potential diplomatic middle ground to be proposed. Maybe we get a couple of sun bears. I'm a big sun bear guy. And to see (ph), you know, I just want to know your take on this. you're an astute observer of all things politics in both countries. What do you think?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: So, to back up my point, right now there are at least 14 zoos in America with sun bears, but there are about two dozen of them in those zoos. That's not nearly enough, in my humble opinion, if I could have one.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That graphic - that graphic was amazing.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Am I supposed to read this?'Phil's love -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I'm checking out of this one.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: 8Phil's love of sun bears caught the attention of the principal of a school in El Paso. This is actually the best thing that happened this week.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: This is great. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How great is that? Making our morning. Don Haskins, a Hall of Fame coach from Texas Western, was nicknamed "the bear," and El Paso is also known as sun city. So, naturally, the sun bears were the perfect mascot.We actually have a panel on this now.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I love it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Look, to be clear, it was the - it was the response from the principal, which was extraordinarily kind. And I appreciated it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She's amazing.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And then the pep rally. That was just cool. That's the only -- we don't actually have a deep (ph) --

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: And they called you Mr. Mattingly.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Which itself is, you know.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That's big.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, no, I - I definitely don't deserve it and I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: But, wait,  you know, this zoo-taliation on - on, you know, (INAUDIBLE), that seems like a very sinister evolution. And don't we get to keep any of the pandas that are born here? Isn't there something -

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: It's very petty, the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It's a program. It's actually - and so the irony of all of this is Culver, David Culver, who is an extraordinary reporter and has great sources.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: This is my point, in both in China and here, the diplomatic ties to this that go back to Nixon are very real.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And I think there's actual concern of, why - why are - why is this happening? And also he pointed out that many of the pandas are now being sent to closer allies than the U.S. including places like Russia and, you know, kind of the new axis that's been described. So, there is a serious piece of this.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Diplomacy.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I just chose not to focus on it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But you - you were the chief White House correspondent --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let me remind people. Before you - thank you for coming here, for waking up in the middle of the night every morning. But is Biden going to bring this up with Xi next week?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I asked Culver -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's a good break the ice.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. He mentioned - Culver mentioned that the Australian prime minister actually brought the issue up, which I thought was interesting. Do I think this is going to come up? Officials were talked about the meeting last night. They did not mention this. I did not ask.I do -- we also do have a very -- another important update that we want to get to. My co-anchor is a published author again. That's right. She already gets up every day to anchor this three-hour show with me.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: With me, while raising two of her own children. And now she's written her second children's book. Just to go off script for a second, it's not easy to do this job at this hour all the time.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It's really not easy to do it when you have kids. Her ability to do it, do it extraordinarily well, and also write a children's book is on some level annoying, but it's also really, really awesome.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You're the best.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The book is called "The Color of Love." She co-wrote it with our former CNN colleague and "Today Show Saturday" anchor Laura Jarrett. The story is about love in all of its forms told through the eyes of a young girl. It comes out on May 14th, but it's already available for pre-order. I think it's pretty clear how I feel about you and your ability to do this.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Phil.Thank you. So sweet.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: What do people need to know?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do I have to actually admit that I wrote this way before I started anchoring this show? Laura and I wrote this together.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: That makes me feel better to some degree.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But thanks for giving me the extra credit. I also raise half as many children as you and Chelsea, so I think I deserve -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The book. It's about the book.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK. OK. OK, it's weird to talk about your own work, but I appreciate it. This book was a pandemic baby of Laura and I. Laura's just such a dear, dear friend and former CNN anchor, as you know, and colleague. And we came together during Covid and after the murder of George Floyd in my hometown of Minneapolis. And we wanted to teach our young children and talk to them about love, not hate, because there was so much focus on hate. And so that is - that is how this came to be.It was a total joy it write it with Laura. And we can't wait for -- we hope people have fun and gain a lot reading it with their kids. It's available May 14th. You can pre-order it now. It's fun.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Congratulation.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: It's gorgeous.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: As a former teacher, I endorse this book wholeheartedly. It's beautiful. I think a lot of -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, you've read it.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ALFORD
utterances.sentences: And I did read it. And the images are stunning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: It was the first book I've read in years, and it was quite good (ph).

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Congratulations, Harry, a big day for you.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The day is May 14th. You can pre-order it now. Poppy dedicates the book to Sienna and Luca.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, I have to mention -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The last book was for Luka. So, Sienna, this one's for you, I promise.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Awe.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Harry, Natasha, John, thanks, guys. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Welcome back.The top ten CNN Heroes of 2023 have been announced. One will be voted CNN Hero of the Year by you, our viewers. We will be introducing each of them to you over the next five weeks, like Dr. Kwane Stewart. He's made it his mission to offer judgement free and essential veterinary care to pets that belong to the growing number of unhoused people on the streets of California. Watch. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DR. KWANE STEWART, CNN HERO: I've seen people give up their meals for their pet, and people who have $3 to their name, and after I'm done with the treatment, they will try and give me that $3. This is your partner, obviously, (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He's my best friend.

utterances.speaker: STEWART
utterances.sentences: They see me with my stethoscope and my bag.Oh, yes, you look good. This little dog was days away from dying. And then they start sharing stories about their dog and the history.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He makes me feel good, and he loves me. And I know he loves me.

utterances.speaker: STEWART
utterances.sentences: I can treat about 80 percent of the cases I see out of a really small bag.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, you do vaccines too. Oh, that's really cool.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How great is that? You can, of course, vote for your hero. Go to cnnheroes.com. By the way, you can vote as many times as you want. We'll keep introducing you to these amazing humans every week right here.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It is Friday. We are done. You should have a great weekend. And just, if we couldn't make our jobs more complicated for our wonderful tech and stage team, we brought a bunch of kids in?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Hi, guys!

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Hi, guys!Packed studio. Have a great weekend. "CNN NEWS CENTRAL" starts right now.
